artefact: Wild and protected bird licence (England, Scotland and Wales)

artefact.overview: You need a licence to kill or take wild birds, take eggs or nests or disturb specially protected birds.
artefact.licence_short_description: Licence to kill or take wild birds, take eggs or nests or disturb specially protected birds in England, Scotland and Wales.
artefact.licence_overview:
If you intend to kill or take wild birds, take eggs or nests or disturb specially protected birds, you need a licence from [Natural England,](http://www.naturalengland.org.uk/ "Natural England"){:rel="external"} [Scottish Natural Heritage](http://www.snh.gov.uk/ "Scottish Natural Heritage"){:rel="external"} or the [Countryside Council for Wales,](http://www.ccw.gov.uk/Splash.aspx "Countryside Council for Wales"){:rel="external"} depending on where the activity is intended to take place.

Wild birds can only be killed or, along with eggs or nests, taken in order to:

* prevent serious damage to livestock, crops, fruit, vegetables, fisheries etc
* prevent the spread of disease
* preserve air safety
* conserve wild birds
* preserve public health or safety

Traps, nets, snares etc that are normally prohibited for killing or taking birds may be used under licence.

Specially protected birds can only be disturbed in order to:

* preserve public health or safety
* monitor or ring them for scientific, research or conservation purposes
* photograph or film them

A list of specially protected birds is available on competent authority websites.

#How to apply

Applications forms are available on the competent authority website and you must use the correct form for the activity you want to carry out.

You must provide your personal details, location and details of the activity you want to carry out, as well as any other information specific to your application.

You should submit the following documents with your application:

- authorisation to use the land for the licensed activity (if you are not the owner or occupier)
- any other information relevant to your application - eg copies of relevant photographs or a conservation report

No fee is payable for a licence.

##Conditions

Licences will state how long they are valid for and any conditions that you must comply with.

General licences are also available for certain activities that affect prescribed species - eg killing crows by a landowner to prevent the spread of disease. You don't need to apply for these licences but you must comply with the conditions attached to them.

##Fines and penalties

%If you fail to obtain a licence or comply with the terms of a licence, you are committing an offence and may be fined, imprisoned for up to six months or both.%
